awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Collaborative Research: CDS&E: Advances in closure modeling for turbulent flows with finite-sized particles informed by massive simulations on heterogeneous architectures
awd_abstract_narration:
Suspensions of solid particles immersed in a fluid – either gas or liquid – are important in many industrial systems and in many natural processes.  Multiphase computational fluid dynamics to predict the behavior of these systems relies on making approximations to the appropriate equations.  As a result, some important phenomena, such as the aggregation of solid particles in the flow, are not accurately predicted.  The formation of particle clusters in gas-solid flows results from complex interactions of the particles with the gas and the particles with each other.  This collaborative Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering (CDS&E) project will develop a modeling framework for particle clustering in gas-flow problems enabled by massive simulations using highly scalable codes.  Numerical techniques developed by the researchers at the three participating institutions will be integrated to formulate a consistent and scalable framework for solving problems in which particle clustering is significant.  The results will enable researchers to tackle problems involving particle clusters such as chemical looping combustion, biomass fast pyrolysis and carbon dioxide capture applications.  Computational data generated in the project will be available to researchers through a web-based interface.  The researchers will use the project to develop educational tools to engage a broad public audience, especially middle and high school students, in displays of the fundamental principles underlying flows of particle suspensions in a gas.

Particle-resolved Direct Numerical Simulation (PR-DNS), which can resolve microscale particle-fluid interactions and point-particle direct numeric simulation (PP-DNS), which can model inter-particle collisions, will be integrated with pseudo-spectral techniques, which have the potential to accelerate computations for gas-solid flows.  Highly scalable PR–DNS and PP-DNS codes will be developed to leverage new algorithmic advances in (a) turbulence simulation using the pseudo-spectral approach on heterogeneous architectures and (b) efficient scaling with number of particles in Eulerian-Lagrangian multiphase flow solvers to perform massive PR–DNS and PP-DNS of canonical clustering flows on scales needed to demonstrate particle clustering.  Consistent scalable closures will be developed for volume-filtered Eulerian-Lagrangian formulations and PP-DNS and PR-DNS.   A consistent averaging operation will be applied on the PR–DNS data that explicitly takes the resolved scales into account, resulting in new unclosed terms that have yet to be quantified in a two-phase context. Novel closure techniques using machine learning will be employed to evaluate the functional form of the new terms.  To maximize their impact on model development, the source codes and canonical multiphase flow data generated in this project will be archived in an open-access database available to the broader scientific community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The development of affordable clean energy solutions is critical to meet limits on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions that drive anthropogenic climate change. Clean and affordable energy generation from biomass through technologies such as pyrolysis or chemical looping combustion involve the flow of gas with particles. This often results in particles forming clusters as they interact with the turbulent motion of the gas phase. This project is focused on advancing the understanding and prediction of turbulence-induced clustering of particles in particle-laden flows,

Computer models of particles interacting with a turbulent gas can be used to predict particle clustering provided they capture all the relevant physical and chemical interactions between particles and turbulent gas flow. These fully accurate models are called particle-resolved direct numerical simulation (PR-DNS) models. Even if we restrict our attention to just the physical interactions, these occur on scales that range from the size of a particle to the scale of the industrial device that can contain trillions of particles. Therefore, computers need to represent very small scale motions and also very large scale motions. The challenge is that accurately representing this wide range of scales of motion requires computers that can store very large amounts of data, and perform calculations extremely rapidly, so that we can get predictions in a timely manner. Even with today’s fastest supercomputers, such calculations can take months to years.

Therefore, there is interest in developing an approximate (but still highly accurate) representation of the gas phase using the volume-filtered Euler Lagrange (VFEL) model, which can perform these calculations on less specialized computers with rapid turnaround time on the order of days to a week. The focus of this project is on developing such approximate VFEL models that are consistent with the most accurate PR-DNS computer models, and which minimally increase computing burden as we increase the size of the problem we wish to solve.

However, in order to make the approximate VFEL model consistent with the fully accurate PR-DNS model, we need to establish the mathematical conditions under which the approximate VFEL is still a highly accurate representation. The project demonstrated that by requiring the consistency of a particular common variable: namely, the variance of the filtered particle volume fraction, we can effectively characterize particle clustering even in VFEL.

In order to demonstrate the validity of this approach, we needed to resort to a third model where an approximate (but still highly accurate) representation of the particle phase using the point particle direct numerical simulation (PP-DNS) model, which can perform calculations of particle clustering on leadership-class computers with rapid turnaround time on the order of days to a week.

This project utilized state-of-the-art computational tools, including the most accurate particle-resolved (PR) and the approximate point-particle (PP) direct numerical simulation data to investigate clustering mechanisms of inertial particles in turbulent particle-laden flows.

We found from analyzing the PP-DNS data on particle clustering that the history of particle interactions with the turbulent gas contribute to the formation of particle clusters. Inspired by this analysis, a scale-dependent path-history particle dynamics model that more comprehensively captures the clustering dynamics of inertial particles was proposed. This model accounts for both local and non-local contributions of the flow field and integrates the Kinematic Simulation-based Sub-Grid Model (KSSGM), which effectively predicts particle clustering for high-inertia particles. Through this model, we aim to bridge the gap between particle-scale and device-scale interactions of fluid and particles, ultimately improving the predictive capabilities of approximate VFEL models for simulating large-scale industrial systems.

These improved models will enable highly accurate simulation of particle clustering in gas-particle suspensions that constitute critical processes in different energy technologies and environmental flows. Such improved models will result in performance gains, improved efficiency, and reliability of industrial clean energy technologies. They will also enable better prediction of pollution arising from environmental disasters and impacts on air and water quality resulting from the effects of climate change.
